verses.text: Then Job answered and said:
verses.comment: This introduces Job’s reply to Eliphaz’s accusations. The dialogue structure continues.

verses.text: I have heard many things like these; you are all miserable comforters.
verses.comment: Job is frustrated by the repeated and unhelpful arguments of his friends. They offer no real comfort (cf. 2 Cor. 1:4 for true comfort).

verses.text: Will useless words have an end? Or what provokes you that you continue to answer?
verses.comment: Job criticizes his friends for their persistence in empty talk. Their arguments lack substance, echoing Paul's call in 1 Cor. 13:1 to speak with love.

verses.text: I also could speak as you do, if your souls were in my soul’s place; I could join words together against you, and shake my head at you.
verses.comment: Job points out the lack of empathy in his friends. True spiritual care includes compassion (see Rom. 12:15).

verses.text: But I would strengthen you with my mouth, and the comfort of my lips would bring relief.
verses.comment: Job contrasts himself with his friends by saying he would offer true comfort. This anticipates the ministry of the 'Suffering Servant' who brings comfort (Isaiah 61:1-2).

verses.text: Even if I speak, my pain is not relieved; and if I refrain, how much of it leaves me?
verses.comment: Job acknowledges that neither expressing nor suppressing his grief eases his suffering, a reminder of the deep mystery of human suffering.

verses.text: But now He has worn me out; You have ruined my entire family.
verses.comment: Here, Job addresses God directly, expressing that his suffering and loss come under God's permissive will (cf. Lamentations 3:37-38).

verses.text: You have seized me; it is a witness against me. My leanness rises up to testify to my face.
verses.comment: Job sees his physical suffering as testimony against him, reminiscent of the scapegoat imagery that later finds fulfillment in the suffering Messiah (cf. Isa. 53:4-5).

verses.text: His anger tears at me and He harasses me; He grinds His teeth against me. My enemy sharpens his eyes on me.
verses.comment: Job attributes his affliction to God's wrath, foreshadowing the mystery of the righteous suffering for reasons unseen, a theme found in Christ's Passion (Mark 15:34).

verses.text: They have opened their mouths wide against me; they have struck my cheek with reproach; they gather together against me.
verses.comment: A prophetic echo: Christ, too, would be shamed and struck (cf. Isaiah 50:6; Matt. 26:67), linking Job’s innocent suffering to Jesus’.

verses.text: God has delivered me into the hands of the wicked, and thrown me into the hands of the unrighteous.
verses.comment: Job’s words anticipate the betrayal and handing over of Christ (Luke 24:7). There is a pattern of the innocent being 'given up' by God for a higher purpose.

verses.text: I was at ease, but He shattered me; He seized me by the neck and broke me apart. He has set me up as His target.
verses.comment: Job describes the abruptness and violence of his suffering. The language recalls that of a sacrifice—God allows suffering for mysterious, redemptive reasons.

verses.text: His archers surround me. He pierces my kidneys without mercy and pours out my gall on the ground.
verses.comment: The graphic language of arrows and piercing points forward to the suffering of Christ on the cross, whose side was pierced (John 19:34).

verses.text: He breaks me with blow after blow; He runs at me like a warrior.
verses.comment: Job’s relentless trials underline the mysterious nature of suffering permitted by God, showing God’s providence even in tribulation.

verses.text: I have sewed sackcloth over my skin and buried my horn in the dust.
verses.comment: Sackcloth, a symbol of mourning and repentance, highlights the spirit of penance and humility (see Joel 2:13).

verses.text: My face is red with weeping, and deep shadows are on my eyelids,
verses.comment: Job’s physical state reflects his inner suffering; genuine grief can be an occasion for spiritual growth (cf. Ps. 126:5).

verses.text: even though there is no violence in my hands, and my prayer is pure.
verses.comment: Job maintains his innocence, foreshadowing the righteousness of Christ, the sinless one who suffers unjustly (1 Pet. 2:22).

verses.text: O earth, do not cover my blood, and let my cry have no resting place.
verses.comment: There is an appeal to divine justice—Job’s cry, like Abel’s (Gen. 4:10), will not go unheard. The innocent blood speaks to God, fulfilled perfectly in Christ (Heb. 12:24).

verses.text: Even now, my witness is in heaven; my advocate is on high.
verses.comment: Job appeals to an intercessor in heaven. Christians see here a foreshadowing of Christ’s priestly intercession for believers (Heb. 7:25; Rom. 8:34).

verses.text: My friends scorn me, but my eyes pour out tears to God,
verses.comment: Job’s suffering is accompanied by prayer. Such perseverance in prayer is commended in all Christian traditions, especially with the understanding of the saints’ intercession (Rev. 5:8).

verses.text: that one might plead for a man with God, as a man pleads for his neighbor.
verses.comment: Job longs for a mediator. In the new covenant, Christ is the only mediator between God and man (1 Tim. 2:5), but the communion of saints share in Christ’s intercessory work as members of His body (see Rev. 8:3-4).

verses.text: For when a few years have come, I will go the way from which I shall not return.
verses.comment: Job refers to the certainty of death. The hope of resurrection and eternal life (see John 5:28-29) develops from meditations on this finality.
